paragraphs.text: Five ways Obama could make Castro pay Cuba's $6 billion debt to Americans.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: In his half century reign of terror, Cuban dictator Fidel Castro committed manifold atrocities
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Documented evidence reveals him to be a ruthless tyrant
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: who endlessly abused the most basic of human rights
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: -a man who played a pivotal role in bringing the world to the precipice of nuclear annihilation for 13 harrowing days in October of 1962
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Beyond his crimes against humanity and the callous suffering he inflicted on the people of Cuba, he ruined the lives and livelihoods of thousands of Americans
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: He stole their land, homes, bank accounts, possessions and businesses
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: He absconded with their property under the guise of "nationalization."
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But he is, in truth, a thief
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Will his victims now be fairly compensated or otherwise see the return of their confiscated property in the wake of America's first steps toward rapprochement with Cuba?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The answer is both legal and political
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: President Obama holds the key
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: So, don't get your hopes up
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Theft
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: In the first half of the 20th century, Americans and U.S  businesses dominated Cuba
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They accumulated vast holdings of property and operated many of the most lucrative businesses
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: All of that ended with the Cuban Revolution in 1959
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Castro "nationalized" U.S.-owned industries and seized much of the island's private property from Americans
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There was no restitution
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: One legal scholar called it the largest uncompensated expropriation by a foreign government in history
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The U.S  retaliated with an embargo, prohibiting all trade
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: But the Americans who were expelled from Cuba were left holding titles and deeds to homes and businesses to which they had no access
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Their property rights were dissolved
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: any legal judgments obtained were unenforceable against an isolated nation that refused to recognize any authority other than its own
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Thousands pursued legal recourse and sought reparations under indemnification programs established by Congress
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Others filed lawsuits and secured judgments
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: But Castro didn't care
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: He repudiated the legitimacy of the restitution programs, the valuation of losses and the legal authority of the courts
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: even though Cuba admits their renegade nationalization was, and is, compensable
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So what
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: then
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: does Castro consider fair compensation?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Judging from his payouts to other aggrieved nations, it is mere pennies on the dollar
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: How
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: do you value dirt?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In 1961, the U.S  Commerce Department valued American property seized by the Cuban government at roughly $ 1 to 1.8 billion
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Nearly 6-thousand claims were legally certified
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Other published reports placed the theft as high as $ 9 billion
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: But the truth is, it's impossible to know -especially inasmuch as the value of everything plummeted the moment Castro took control of the island
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What would the same confiscated properties be worth in today's dollars?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: $50 billion?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: $100 billion?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: How about nothing at all?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Given how the Castro brothers have driven their economy into the ground, making Cuba one of the poorest nations in the world
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: valuation could be closer to dirt than dollars
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Which invites another question
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: assuming a monetary value could somehow be devised, how would Cuba pay for it?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: With the collapse of the Soviet Union, the Castros lost their financial benefactor
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The island is blighted and broke
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Even if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it offered government bonds as compensation
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: , are they worth the paper upon which they are written?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: How could they be secured?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Reclaim the property?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Theoretically, it is possible for the confiscated property to be reclaimed someday by the original owners
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: But that would require a dramatic Cuban transformation from socialism to democracy where private property ownership is permitted
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In a recent speech, Cuban President Raul Castro insisted Cuba would not renounces its core socialist ideals as part of the deal he negotiated with President Obama to renew diplomatic relations
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Even if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: some semblance of democracy were to be restored to Cuba in the distant future
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: what remains of the stolen property?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: No one knows how many of the private residences that were seized have been divided or fallen into decay
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Some may no longer exist
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: And what of the current occupants?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Would they allow themselves to be kicked out?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The same may be true of the many farms, industries and commercial businesses that were confiscated and have been put to other uses in the last 5 decades
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Yes, they have development potential in an open, free market society
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: again, the future of Cuba is nebulous
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: How realistic is the return of these vast holdings under a continuing Castro regime?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What Obama should do
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As a first condition to normalizing relations, President Obama should demand that all American victims of stolen property be compensated equitably
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: He is already obligated by law to do this under the Helms-Burton Act
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But Obama has a propensity to ignore or overrule with impunity those laws he regards as misguided or inconvenient
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This is one law he should follow
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A second condition should be the establishment of a commission of judges with legally binding authority to render compensation decisions
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Several reparation models can be studied and replicated, notably the tribunal that dispensed claims in post-unification Germany
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: President Obama has the power and leverage to force the Castro regime to capitulate if Cuba wants to end the sanctions and restore economic relations
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But so far, he has uttered not a word about a desire to do so
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: when it comes to negotiations with adversaries, Obama tends to give away the store
paragraphs.label: assumption
